title: Labor's new climate message: it's about jobs
text:
"According to forecasts of global growth in wind power capacity to 2030, Australia could be exporting 15.5 million tonnes of coking coal to build these turbines.

"The road to a low carbon future can be paved with hundreds of thousands of clean energy jobs, as well as supporting traditional jobs, including coal mining.''

Extracts of Mr Albanese's speech, to be delivered in Perth today, underscore Labor's post-election push to shift its policy emphasis towards economic growth, rather than just raising and redistributing revenue.

"Like Bob Hawke and Paul Keating, I understand that building the future means we must first and foremost be in the business of creating wealth, as well as ensuring it is distributed fairly,'' he will say.

"Labor is proudly and resolutely pro-growth.''

Last week, in the face of union pressure, Mr Albanese defended Labor's support for free trade deals with Indonesia, Hong Kong and Peru as being good for jobs.

Similarly, Mr Albanese's key message today will be to reframe the sales pitch for climate change policy.

Advertisement

As well as the problem in coal seats which was exacerbated by ambiguity towards the Adani coal mine, then-leader Bill Shorten struggled on the campaign trail with questions about the economic cost of Labor's climate change policy.

The policy included a 50 per cent renewable energy target by 2030 and a cap-and-trade system on industry's heavy emitters.

Today, Mr Albanese will sharpen the policy pitch to one of job creation in both new and traditional industries.

"The world is decarbonising,'' he will say.

"With the right planning and vision, Australia can not only continue to be an energy exporting superpower, we can also enjoy a new manufacturing boom.

"This means jobs.''

Critical minerals

He lists as a prime example the opportunity to value-add critical minerals such as lithium by manufacturing batteries, rather than exporting the raw mineral and importing batteries.

Advertisement

"As electrical vehicles, energy storage systems and smart devices become more mainstream, the global demand for lithium batteries will explode.''

He will cite Western Australia's seven lithium mines, its two processing plants and plans for a third.

"The emerging lithium industry is a living example of how real world economic progress happens – business, unions, researchers and government coming together to deliver on an aspiration bigger than just digging stuff out of the ground and letting the value-adding happen offshore,'' he will say.

"Not only is Australia in a position to build the batteries, Brisbane-based company Tritium has developed and is already exporting the technology to recharge them. Their charging stations are the fastest in the world, and are fuelling the shift to electric vehicles in Europe."

Mr Albanese will stress that other minerals such as rare earths, copper and silver, of which Australia has vast reserves, will become increasingly vital as energy and other technologies evolve.

But he will reassure that these new and developing industries will not come at the immediate expense of "traditional industries'' such as coal.

He will say an estimated 15.5 million tonnes of coking coal needed to produce the global growth in wind farms forecast by 2030 was the equivalent of three years' production from the Moranbah North coal mine in Queensland.

Advertisement

At the May 18 election, marginal seats in central and north Queensland, which Labor had hoped to win, swung against it due to Labor's perceived disdain for coal mining.

Similarly, frontbencher Joel Fitzgibbon was given a fright in his supposedly safe Hunter Valley seat.

Since the election, Mr Albanese has also sought to build bridges with the business community, which was derided by Labor before the election as "the top end of town''.

Mr Albanese will make further overtures towards business today.

Investment allowance

"We understand that successful businesses and vibrant economy are essential prerequisites for job growth,'' he will say.

"Ensuring they thrive and flourish is vital to our national prosperity.''

In this vein, he will again call on the government to bring forward from the May budget its plans for an investment allowance to encourage business investment and stimulate the economy.

Advertisement

Labor took an investment allowance to the last election as a substitute for the company tax cuts it opposed and Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has flagged there will be such a policy in the budget, scheduled to be handed down on May 12.

"I call upon the government to introduce an upgraded investment guarantee as part of a measured economic stimulus package to boost our sluggish economy,'' Mr Albanese will say.

"A bring-forward of infrastructure investment combined with increased business investment would create jobs in the short term as well as lift productivity.''

Mr Albanese will also chip the government over a lack of settled energy policy, saying this, too, was acting as a deterrence to business investment.
description: Anthony Albanese has recast Labor's climate change policy pitch to one of job creation and economic growth.
